questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to an infectious disease specialist for follow-up regarding a new diagnosis of hepatitis C. He was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis C several weeks ago after he presented with malaise, fatigue, and elevated liver enzymes. He is a healthcare provider and thinks he may have contracted the disease via an accidental needlestick injury several years ago. He was initially prescribed medications to help treat the disease. His viral titer at today’s visit remains high, and his physician subsequently prescribes an additional medication that works by preventing viral maturation through inhibition of protein synthesis. Which of the following is the most likely side effect of the aforementioned medication used to treat this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for follow up regarding a recent diagnosis and initiation of treatment for chronic hepatitis C infection. He is prescribed a new medication that works by preventing viral maturation through inhibition of protein synthesis, consistent with the NS3/4A inhibitors grazoprevir and simeprevir. These medications are commonly associated with headache and photosensitivity.  

Unlike other forms of viral hepatitis, several medications are FDA approved for the treatment and eradication of chronic hepatitis infection. It is important to note that the following list of medications are never used as monotherapy but rather in combination with one another to have a synergistic effect against the virus.  

  • The non-structural protein 5A inhibitors ledipasvir and ombitasvir work via inhibition of a phosphoprotein that inhibits the viral RNA replication cycle; however, the exact mechanism of action has not been elucidated.  
  • The non-structural protein 5B inhibitors sofosbuvir and dasabuvir work by acting as a chain terminator in the viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.  
  • The non-structural protein NS3/4A inhibitors grazoprevir simeprevir work via inhibition of a viral protease, terminating effective protein synthesis and thus viral replication. 

All of these drugs carry the side effects of headache, while photosensitivity is a side effect unique to the NS3/4A inhibitors. An alternative medication, although used less commonly in the treatment of hepatitis C, is ribavirin. This medication, while used more commonly to treat respiratory syncytial virus, works by competitively inhibiting IMP dehydrogenase. It carries a risk of teratogenicity and hemolytic anemia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Headache and photosensitivity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Obstructive crystalline uropathy:
Incorrect: The antiviral medications acyclovir, famciclovir, valacyclovir are used in the treatment of herpetic infection and zoster. They carry an increased risk of crystallization in urine, potentially resulting in acute kidney injury.
❌ Bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Bone marrow suppression is an important side effect of ganciclovir, which is used to treat CMV infection. It has no role in the treatment of hepatitis C.
❌ Vivid dreams:
Incorrect: The HIV medication efavirenz is commonly associated with inducing vivid dreams, as well as central nervous symptoms, rash and hepatotoxicity. It has no role in the treatment of hepatitis C.
❌ Increase in creatinine kinase:
Incorrect: The HIV integrase inhibitors dolutegravir, elvitegravir, and raltegravir are associated with increased levels of creatinine kinase and rhabdomyolysis. It has no role in the treatment of hepatitis C.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of intractable vomiting and lethargy. The patient’s parent reports that the family was on vacation for the past six days. Three days ago, the patient developed a headache, cough, coryza, sore throat and a temperature of 39.2°C (102.6°F). The parent reports that the patient was given multiple medications to bring down his fever. The fever resolved yesterday, but the patient has become increasingly lethargic and began having non-bilious, non-bloody emesis one day prior to presentation. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min and blood pressure is 95/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows a lethargic child who is minimally reactive. Abdominal examination reveals mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following medications is the most likely etiology of this patient’s current condition?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14.5 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  8000/mm3 
 Platelet count    180,000/mm3 
 Serum  
 Creatinine   0.6 g/dL 
 BUN  10 mg/dL 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   0.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  0.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT  405 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT  417 U/L 
 Ammonia  94 mcg/dL 
 Coagulation studies
 Prothrombin time  19 sec 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time  45 sec
questions.solution:
This patient presents with vomiting, lethargy, hepatomegaly and laboratory evidence of hepatic injury after taking over-the-counter medications for a presumed viral infection. Together, these findings are suspicious for Reye syndrome secondary to aspirin administration.   

Reye syndrome is caused by aspirin metabolites that inhibit hepatic mitochondrial enzymes, thereby decreasing beta-oxidation in the liver. This manifests clinically with nausea, vomiting, encephalopathy and hepatomegaly. Laboratory derangements include abnormal hepatic aminotransferases, coagulation profile (prolonged PT and PTT) and hyperammonemia. Histologically, the liver may demonstrate microvesicular steatosis, which is characterized by small intracytoplasmic liposomes within hepatocytes that do not distort the hepatocyte nucleus. Aspirin is generally contraindicated in children except in the case of Kawasaki disease and juvenile idiopathic arthritis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is the antipyretic/analgesic of choice in children with viral infections. Its use is not associated with the development of Reye syndrome.
✅ Aspirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Celecoxib:
Incorrect: Celecoxib is a cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitor, which can be used as an anti-inflammatory agent in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. It does not have antipyretic effects and is not associated with the development of Reye syndrome.
❌ Cetirizine:
Incorrect: Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine that is typically used in the management of seasonal allergies.  It does not have an antipyretic effect and is not associated with the development of Reye syndrome.   
❌ Diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine is a second-generation antihistamine that is typically used in the management of allergic reactions. It does not have an antipyretic effect and is not associated with the development of Reye syndrome.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden abdominal pain and nausea that started last night. The patient’s medical history includes severe chronic alcohol use disorder, and he reports drinking a liter of vodka every day for the past week. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 37.7ºC (99.9ºF), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 19/min and blood pressure is 132/94 mmHg. The patient appears uncomfortable and in mild distress. Physical examination shows an exquisitely tender epigastrium with bruising of his lower abdomen, as shown in the image below.  

 


Image reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is most likely contributing to this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Increased bicarbonate secretion by ductal epithelial cells

questions.solution:
This patient’s acute epigastric pain (often radiating to the back) with nausea and periumbilical bruising (Cullen’s Sign) are highly suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Acute pancreatitis is characterized by sudden inflammation and hemorrhaging of the pancreas due to destruction by its own enzymes (autodigestion). The most common causes of acute pancreatitis are 1) gallstones and 2) chronic alcohol abuse; this patient’s long standing heavy drinking is the likely cause of his pancreatitis.  

Alcohol consumption leads to decreased fluid and bicarbonate secretion by the pancreatic ductal epithelial cells. This causes thickened pancreatic juices that can plug and block the pancreatic ducts, and the increasing pressure and distention results in dysfunctional cellular membrane trafficking. In addition to fluid and bicarbonate secretion, pancreatic exocrine acinar cells also secrete digestive enzymes that help break down the proteins, carbohydrates, and lipids found in food. Alcohol independently causes increased secretion of acinar cell zymogen granules (vesicles filled with proto-enzymes, especially trypsinogen), which can fuse with lysosomes in the setting of altered membrane trafficking. The result is activation of trypsinogen into trypsin by the lysosomal proteases and subsequent breakdown of cellular structures by trypsin. A flood of inflammatory cytokines are released, in addition to those independently induced by alcohol itself, attracting neutrophils that produce superoxides and more proteases. This chain reaction of cellular destruction may progress and cause blood vessel leakage along with lipase-mediated pancreatic fat destruction, culminating in liquefactive hemorrhagic necrosis.  

With hemorrhagic pancreatitis, a faint blue discoloration around the umbilicus (Cullen’s sign) may occur as a result of hemoperitoneum, and a blue-red-purple or green-brown discoloration of the flanks (Grey Turner’s sign) may appear from tissue catabolism of hemoglobin in the setting of severe necrotizing disease. However, these signs are not present in most cases of acute pancreatitis, which are mild to moderate and self-limited.  



Option Analysis

✅ Increased zymogen granule secretion  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased reactive oxygen species production:
Incorrect: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are increased in the setting of acute pancreatitis, where activated neutrophils release superoxides locally and perpetuate inflammation.  
❌ Ampulla of Vater obstruction:
Incorrect: Ampulla of Vater (hepatopancreatic ampulla) obstruction can result in gallstone pancreatitis, but it is not a causative factor in alcohol-induced pancreatitis.  
❌ Decreased cytokine release:
Incorrect: Alcohol stimulates the release of inflammatory cytokines, which generate a strong immune reaction and contribute to acute alcohol-induced pancreatitis.  
❌ Increased bicarbonate secretion by ductal epithelial cells:
Incorrect: Alcohol decreases fluid and bicarbonate production by pancreatic ductal epithelial cells, leading to viscous pancreatic secretions and duct plugging.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman with a history of chronic alcohol use disorder comes to the office because of diarrhea, generalized weakness, and a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. She reports intermittent dull upper abdominal pain that will last for days at a time and is not improved with antacids. After meals, she feels that her abdomen is distended. She characterizes her multiple daily bowel movements as greasy, foul-smelling, and oily. She recently was the driver involved in a minor traffic accident, which she attributes to worsening eyesight at night. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows resonance to percussion throughout and a mildly tender epigastrium. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. Laboratory values show the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Calcium, serum  7.6 mg/dL 
 Partial thromboplastin time  60 seconds 
 Prothrombin time  28 seconds 

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's diarrhea?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has pancreatic exocrine dysfunction secondary to chronic pancreatitis from chronic heavy alcohol consumption. Continuous inflammation or repeated episodes of acute pancreatitis results in replacement of normal pancreatic parenchyma with fibrotic tissue, leading to the loss of pancreatic exocrine acinar cells. These cells contain digestive enzymes (including trypsinogen) that are secreted into the pancreatic ducts and subsequently activated in the duodenum to digest food into its absorbable components. When these cells and enzymes are lost, dietary lipids cannot be absorbed. As a consequence, patients may experience features of fat malabsorption including fatty diarrhea (steatorrhea) and fat-soluble vitamin (A, D, E, & K) deficiency. Malabsorption of the fat-soluble vitamins may cause their respective deficiency symptoms:  


This patient is experiencing visual difficulties while driving most likely due to vitamin A deficiency. Her laboratory values show hypocalcemia due to vitamin D deficiency, and a prolonged PT and aPTT due to vitamin K deficiency. Appropriate pancreatic enzyme replacement will improve this patient’s ability to absorb these fat-soluble vitamins and improve her steatorrhea.  

Option Analysis

❌ Carcinoid tumor:
Incorrect: Carcinoid tumors most commonly occur in the gastrointestinal tract and can cause carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by secretory diarrhea, flushing, tachycardia, and right-sided heart failure. 
❌ Celiac disease:
Incorrect: Celiac disease causes malabsorption via an inflammatory autoimmune response to dietary gluten; however, in the setting of chronic heavy alcohol use, pancreatic insufficiency secondary to chronic alcohol-related pancreatitis is a more likely diagnosis.
❌ Chronic gastritis:
Incorrect: Chronic gastritis is common with long standing heavy alcohol intake and may cause epigastric pain; however, it does not cause malabsorption or diarrhea.
✅ Chronic pancreatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pancreatic adenocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma can produce weight loss and abdominal discomfort but would be unlikely to cause diarrhea. A mass in the head of the pancreas may cause obstructive jaundice and elevations in serum liver enzymes.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of epigastric abdominal pain and unintentional weight loss. The symptoms began 6 months ago and the patient has lost 4 kg (8.8 lb) during this time period. Review of systems is notable for fatigue and pruritus over this same time period. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder. The patient has a 35-pack-year smoking history. In the office, his temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 125/77 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination shows an enlarged, palpable, but non-tender, gallbladder. Examination of the patient’s eyes reveals the following finding:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Cardiac and pulmonary exams are noncontributory. Serum carbohydrate antigen 19-9 levels are elevated. Which of the following laboratory findings would most likely be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has pancreatic cancer. The tumor can impinge the bile duct, obstruct outflow, and cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Patients with pancreatic cancer can develop jaundice, scleral icterus, epigastric pain, weight loss, and night sweats. Of note, the image in this vignette shows scleral icterus. Patients can also have the Trousseau sign of malignancy (superficial blood clots; also known as Trousseau syndrome) and, as in this patient, the Courvoisier sign (enlarged, palpable, yet non-tender gallbladder and accompanying jaundice).  

Other causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia include reduced bilirubin excretion (e.g. Dubin-Johnson syndrome), biliary tract conditions (e.g. primary sclerosing cholangitis), and biliary tract obstruction (e.g. choledocolithiasis). In the aforementioned etiologies, conjugated bilirubin can deposit in tissues and cause pruritus. In these conditions, less conjugated bilirubin reaches the intestines. As a result, there is less conversion of bilirubin into urobilinogen, and therefore, less urobilinogen is reabsorbed and excreted via urine. Ultimately, patients will have low urine urobilinogen levels.   

In contrast, for patients with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, bile outflow is unaffected. Thus patients with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia have either normal or elevated urine urobilinogen levels (depending on the specific etiology). 

Option Analysis

❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine urobilinogen Normal  Normal  Normal :
Incorrect:  These findings would be seen in a healthy individual. However, this patient has jaundice and scleral icterus, which are concerning for elevated bilirubin levels. Hence, either unconjugated or conjugated bilirubin levels should be elevated.
❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine urobilinogen  ↑ Normal  ↑:
Incorrect: Prehepatic and intrahepatic etiologies can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Since bile outflow is not affected, urine urobilinogen levels are either normal or elevated. However, this patient's history, physical exam findings, and elevated CA 19-9 are concerning for pancreatic cancer. Pancreatic cancer can compress the biliary tree, impair bile outflow, and cause elevated conjugated bilirubin levels.  
✅  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine urobilinogen Normal  ↑ ↓:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine urobilinogen ↑ ↑ ↓:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with mixed hyperbilirubinemia, which is often due to jaundice or cirrhosis. However, this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with pancreatic cancer, which would most likely cause purely conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and reduced urine urobilinogen levels secondary to impaired bile outflow.
❌   Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine urobilinogen  ↑ Normal  Normal :
Incorrect: Prehepatic and intrahepatic etiologies can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Since bile outflow is not affected in these etiologies, urine urobilinogen is either normal or elevated. However, this patient’s history and physical exam findings are suggestive of pancreatic cancer, which would cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
